Award.AwardTitle: Small angle x-ray scattering studies of biological macromolecules at cryogenic temperatures
Award.AbstractNarration:
A protein's biological job is related to its shape, thus insight can be gained into a protein's function by measuring its structure and how this structure changes as the protein interacts with other molecules. This task is challenging because many proteins are small, with diameters about ten thousand times less than the width of a human hair. The field of structural biology relies on exploiting experimental methods that provide accurate structural information on such small length scales. In the last decade, thanks to the availability of high intensity x-ray beams at national facilities (synchrotron sources) as well as the development of sophisticated analysis programs that return structural envelopes, small angle x-ray scattering (SAXS) has become a reliable tool for rapidly obtaining structures of proteins and other large biological molecules. The greatest strength of SAXS is its ability to report structures of biological macromolecules in
solution, without the need for specialized sample preparation. A protein's shape can now be determined in a simple and straightforward way. However, the radiation used to measure the sample can also damage it, changing its structure. This problem has been encountered in other radiation-based methods, including x-ray crystallography and electron microscopy. For these latter fields, the use of cryo-freezing has reduced damage to tolerable levels: biological samples are protected from radiation at temperatures of ~100 K. The goal of this project is to design and construct two instruments that will prepare flash-frozen samples optimized for SAXS experiments: cryo-SAXS. Because frozen samples can tolerate longer exposure to radiation, without concern for radiation-induced structural changes, this method will allow structures to be obtained from even small amounts of precious sample. The successful demonstration of cryo-SAXS will garner tremendous interest within the large structural biology community. All plans/designs generated as a result of this project will be made public, through journal publication, presentations at conferences, posting on existing public forums for crystallography and SAXS, and webinars. Dissemination through use at synchrotron sources is also extremely effective, as a large number of users pass through and are exposed to new technologies through users' meetings, facility websites and workshops. A long-term goal of this project is to develop a kit that makes this technology easily available to the structural biology community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this NSF award we made significant progress towards developing an instrument that can improve our understanding of structural biology, by measuring the shapes, or changing shapes of biological macromolecules. The shape of biological macromolecules, like proteins, DNA or RNA,  is often critical to their function: two molecules that are designed to interact have shapes that fit together perfectly, like puzzle pieces.  Shape changes are also critical: these molecules fold up to acquire their biologically active shapes. Sometimes, they don’t fold properly and the misfolded molecules don’t work.

X-ray scattering is an ideal method for making these measurements. X-rays are a type of light, but with a much shorter wavelength. They can, therefore, ‘see’ objects that are much smaller than those we detect with visible light.

X-rays are used in different ways to measure the shapes of these molecules. This work focuses on solution, small angle x-ray scattering or SAXS. The biomolecules of interest float around in liquid, where they are free to change shape.  Past SAXS studies have been very useful in revealing the structures of molecules, and complexes of molecules; however the technique is limited by several challenges. First: the x-rays used to measure the molecule can also damage it (so called radiation damage). Second: traditional solution scattering uses micro-liter volumes of solution. This doesn’t sound like a lot, but some of these molecules can be very hard to manufacture,  so it can be hard to acquire enough to fill a sample cell.  The use of larger volumes is important in reducing the effects of radiation damage: the sample is usually moved through the beam to spread out the exposure. Third, some proteins are less robust than others, forming incorrect bonds or contacts as they age in solution. Other proteins simply degrade with time.

 

To solve these problems, we proposed to ‘flash freeze’ samples, and examine interaction of x-rays with frozen solutions: cryo-SAXS. Radiation damage is reduced in frozen samples, for example although damaging radicals readily diffuse through water, they cannot diffuse through ice.  If we don’t have to be concerned about radiation damage, we don’t need to make as much sample: we can always look at the same, small volume. Finally, freezing samples preserves them, and prevents age-dependent problems. We also studied the process of x-ray damage to proteins in SAXS measurements, an important step in ensuring that SAXS data are accurate.

The main challenge we faced with this project was finding a way to extract the scattering from just the protein samples alone in a frozen sample.  Each protein is kept in a solution containing buffer (mostly water), and held in a container. The x-rays interact with all of these components in the course of a measurement. To extract the scattering of just the protein, we first measure the scattering of a container full of proteins in buffer, and then subtract the scattering of the container that just contains buffer (everything present except for the proteins). This is a standard method for measuring protein structures with SAXS at a single temperature. One of the greatest challenges we faced was designing a container that doesn’t change (or changes in a reproducible way) when the solution is frozen.  We also wanted to make a container with a very small sample volume.

We decided to use a tiny, open box as a container. To make this tiny box, we etched a deep, rectangular hole into a single crystalline piece of silicon. The etching process removes materials along certain directions within the crystal, so the box doesn’t look exactly rectangular. A cartoon of the box is shown in Figure 1. It resembles a tiny shoebox, without a top, and holds a volume that is about one hundredth (.01 times) of the volume of a drop of water. We place the sample in the box, and freeze it in seconds, by blowing liquified nitrogen at it. We successfully measured the scattering of the protein using this method by shooting x-rays through the thin walls of the box (see figure). Although these boxes worked well, we noticed cracks in the ice that developed at the corners of the box. These cracks introduced very small but non-reproducible changes in the scattering profiles. We arrived at a final design that should solve all of the problems, using sample cells with no corners.

With this new design, many identical copies of the sample cell can be fabricated and sequentially probed with x-rays. Background buffer signal can be reliably subtracted, and a new high throughput method for looking at structures can be implemented. Cryo-SAXS, when fully functional, will allow us to study precious samples, as well as those that age quickly or are too sensitive to radiation to be examined at room temperature.
